title: 115_hr3052
content: The Act is titled the "Flexibility to Innovate for College Affordability Act". It establishes a Higher Education Regulatory Reform Task Force. The "Flexibility to Innovate for College Affordability Act" establishes the Higher Education Regulatory Reform Task Force within 2 months of enactment. The Task Force includes the Secretary of Education, heads of relevant Federal agencies, a representative from the Advisory Committee on Student Financial Assistance, and representatives from the higher education community. The Higher Education Regulatory Reform Task Force includes institutions of higher education, nonprofit organizations, and other entities determined appropriate by the Secretary of Education. The Task Force must submit a report on regulatory reform within 6 months of the Act's enactment. The Higher Education Regulatory Reform Task Force will prioritize reviewing regulations related to State authorization of distance education, IPEDS, OMB's A-21 Circular, and reporting under the Jeanne Clery Act for the Regulatory Reform Report. The Higher Education Regulatory Reform Report will include a list of outdated, duplicate, ineffective, or burdensome rules for institutions of higher education. It will also cover various regulatory requirements such as default rates, gainful employment, revenue requirements, and audits. The Higher Education Regulatory Reform Report will include an analysis of the costs and benefits of existing rules, recommendations for simplifying or repealing rules, and justification for these recommendations, including financial impacts on different types of higher education institutions. The Higher Education Regulatory Reform Report will establish a permanent entity to review new regulatory requirements for institutions of higher education. The Secretary of Education must publish the report in the Federal Register for public notice and comment at least 30 days before submission to Congress. The report can be modified in response to comments received. The term "institution of higher education" is defined as per section 102 of the Higher Education Act of 1965, excluding certain institutions. The President must propose implementing recommendations from the Higher Education Regulatory Reform Report to Congress within 120 days of its submission. This includes transmitting a special message with a bill to carry out the recommendations. The President must propose implementing recommendations from the Higher Education Regulatory Reform Report to Congress within 120 days of its submission. The President may transmit one special message each year with a bill to carry out the recommendations. Within 14 days of the bill submission, the majority leaders of the House and Senate must introduce the bill. Any House committee to which the bill is referred must report it without amendment within 14 days. The bill must be reported by a committee without amendment within 14 legislative days after its introduction. If the committee fails to do so or if the House is adjourning sine die, the committee will be discharged from further consideration of the bill. The bill must be considered within 21 legislative days after being reported or after the committee has been discharged. The motion to proceed with a bill in the House is highly privileged, not debatable, and can only be made within two legislative days after the proponent announces their intention. This motion is not allowed after the House has already dealt with a similar motion. The motion to proceed with a bill in the House is highly privileged and not debatable. It can only be made within two legislative days after the proponent announces their intention. If agreed to, the House shall immediately proceed to consider the bill without any intervening motion. All points of order against the bill are waived. The House motion to proceed with a bill is highly privileged and not debatable, with immediate consideration without intervening motion. In the Senate, the appropriate committee must report the bill without amendment within seven session days after introduction. The Senate committee must report a bill within a specified period, or if the Senate plans to adjourn, the Committee will be discharged from further consideration. A motion to proceed with the bill in the Senate can be made within 3 session days without debate. The Senate must report a bill within a specified period, or the Committee will be discharged. A motion to proceed with the bill in the Senate can be made within 3 session days without debate. If agreed to, the Senate will immediately proceed to consideration of the bill without any intervening business. The bill will remain the unfinished business of the Senate until disposed of. In the Senate, consideration of a draft bill is limited to 10 hours, with all debatable motions and appeals equally divided. Points of order against the bill are waived, and certain motions are not allowed. No amendments or motions to strike provisions from the draft bill are allowed in the House of Representatives or the Senate. If one House receives a bill from the other, the receiving House's procedure remains the same until the vote on passage, at which point the received bill supplants the receiving House's bill. For the purpose of this section, continuity of a session of Congress is only broken by adjournment sine die. Days when a House is not in session due to an adjournment of more than 3 days are excluded in calculating any period. SEC. 4. EXPANDING THE EXPERIMENTAL SITES INITIATIVE. Section 487A(b)(3) of the Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to allow the Secretary to waive requirements related to grant and loan maximum award amounts for experimental purposes. The Higher Education Act of 1965 allows institutions to conduct experiments to increase Federal Pell Grant and loan award amounts for students with workloads exceeding full-time academic requirements, aiming to reduce the total cost of attendance. The Secretary can waive requirements for institutions participating in experiments to provide Federal grant and loan awards to students in remedial courses or competency-based learning programs. The Secretary may waive requirements for institutions to offer competencies for success in certain programs, allow students to pay for tests for academic credit, or enroll secondary school students in courses to decrease total cost of attendance.
